Trying on the ankle boots again is a great idea, and returning them if they don't fit is always an option.

Breaking in new shoes, especially ankle boots, can be a challenge, but don't worry, I've got some tips to help you ease into them:

1. **Wear them around the house**: Before taking your new ankle boots out for a spin, wear them around the house for a few hours to help your feet get used to the new shape and material.
2. **Use shoe stretchers or stuffers**: If the boots are a bit tight, try using shoe stretchers or stuffers to help loosen them up. You can also use paper towels or newspaper to stuff the toes and help stretch the material.
3. **Apply heat**: Use a hair dryer or a warm cloth to heat up the areas that feel tight. This can help soften the material and make it more pliable.
4. **Condition the leather**: If your ankle boots are made of leather, use a leather conditioner to soften the material and make it more comfortable.
5. **Gradually increase wear time**: Start with short wear sessions and gradually increase the time as your feet become more comfortable.
6. **Consider a break-in spray**: There are various break-in sprays available that can help soften the material and reduce discomfort. However, always read the instructions and test the spray on a small, inconspicuous area first.
7. **Walk around**: Take short walks around the block or up and down the stairs to help your feet get used to the new boots.
8. **Try different socks**: Sometimes, a thicker or thinner sock can make a big difference in how comfortable your shoes feel. Experiment with different socks to find the perfect combination.
9. **Give them time**: Breaking in new shoes takes time, so be patient and don't get discouraged if they don't feel perfect right away.
10. **Consider a professional cobbler**: If your ankle boots are still uncomfortable after trying the above methods, consider taking them to a professional cobbler who can help stretch or modify the shoes to fit your feet better.

Remember, breaking in new shoes is a process, and it may take some time for your feet to adjust. But with patience and persistence, you'll be strutting around in your new ankle boots in no time!
